boardgame.name: Ashes Reborn: Ashes 1.5 Upgrade Kit
boardgame.description:
This Upgrade Kit give players updated Ashes cards (revised cards that needed to be rebalanced, simplified, or otherwise changed to fit in with the new ruleset) and an updated rulebook.

Components: 378 Updated cards, version 1.5 of the rule book, and a “What’s New” sheet
boardgame.boardgameaccessory: Ashes Reborn: Rise of the Phoenixborn

boardgame.name: Weiß Schwarz: Love Live! Trial Deck
boardgame.description:
Weiß Schwarz is a CCG produced in collaboration with some of the most popular animation/ video game works in Japan. Players separate the "Weiß" side which features mainly pretty characters from the "Schwarz" side featuring cool characters.

Though the title consists of various kinds of card sets, a carefully planned system and rules make it possible for players to mix any of them on each side and enjoy the game.

---

This Series includes characters from Love Live!
boardgame.boardgameintegration: Weiß Schwarz: Attack on Titan Trial Deck
Weiß Schwarz: BanG Dream! Trial Deck
Weiß Schwarz: Sword Art Online Trial Deck
Weiß Schwarz: Attack on Titan Trial Deck
Weiß Schwarz: BanG Dream! Trial Deck
Weiß Schwarz: Sword Art Online Trial Deck

boardgame.name: DreamQuest
boardgame.description:
DreamQuest is a co-operative adventure game for two players — ideally one adult and one child, who take on the roles of Protector and Dreamer.

Together you are trying to complete a quest before the Dreamer awakens, choosing the path to follow, making decisions, fighting monsters, rolling dice, and trying to reach the end of the adventure in time. If the Dreamer rises before the end of the quest, you must start the adventure again, but the heroes now having gained experience that will make them more powerful.

DreamQuest also includes an illustrated book that you can use to record your adventure, personalizing the record for recollection later.

boardgame.name: Improbable Villains Volume Four
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Improbable Villains brings you more antagonists in this fan-favorite line that are both odd and sinister:

Improbable Villains includes:

Mother Gaia - Powerful sorceress who is allied with nature but on self-destructive quest for revenge
Mudslide - Greedy geomorph thug out to make a name for himself in the super powered villain game
Murk - Juvenile delinquent who stumbled onto a old grimoire that granted her control of elemental darkness..for a price
Savage- Hero hunting mercenary with a high tech battlesuit
Syncrhros - Time-jumping thief with delusions of changing the prime timeline.

boardgame.name: Grossdeutschland 1944
boardgame.description:
This Panzer Grenadier: Broken Axis expansion booklet contains 20 tactical-level scenarios (linkable into four “battle games”) set during the Soviet invasion of Romania in 1944. Mustered against two Soviet armies are a miscellany of German and Romanian units. Four scenarios center on the SS “Death’s Head” Division and are designed to shatter illusions about that formation’s “elite” status.

In addition to boards and counters from Broken Axis, most scenarios require components from one or more of Kursk: South Flank, Fire in the Steppe and Armata Romana.

The booklet takes its name from its feature article on the famous Grossdeutschland Division and the included set of 64 die-cut counters portraying its lower level units in the division’s color scheme. The counters aren’t actually used in any of the booklet’s scenarios. They are provided for the numerous Broken Axis scenarios in which the Grossdeutschland fought. Other articles in the booklet discuss the Romanian Royal Army and Soviet armored fighting vehicles employed in the Romanian campaign.

Note: This booklet should not be confused with Panzer Lion: Grossdeutschland 1944, a long out-of-print Panzer Grenadier supplement that portrayed the division’s actions in Romania and was superseded by Broken Axis.
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Broken Axis: The Invasion of Romania, 1944 – A Panzer Grenadier Game

boardgame.name: Burg Klapperfalle
Patatrap Quest
boardgame.description:
To win Patatrap Quest, you need to be the first player to successfully attack the "Big Bad" in the castle three times.

The castle consists of a wall of mirrors surrounding a central pillar. On a turn, roll the dice, then move a distance equal to either die face or the sum of the die faces. When you land on a space in the castle, your figure pushes down a lever and whatever is depicted underneath that lever is then visible in the mirror. Sometimes you get to collect equipment, sometimes you must swap planks, and sometimes you do other things.

When you have the right equipment and can access the staircase to the top of the pillar, you can confront the Big Bad. Draw the topmost token of its stack, then look at the back of it in secret. If you can discard the item depicted, you collect that token; otherwise, you're ejected from the castle and must start moving in again. The first player to collect three tokens wins.

Patatrap Quest includes five Big Bads, each with its own stack of tokens.

boardgame.name: Fistful of Lead: Snowbrawl!
boardgame.description:
Fistful of Lead: Snowbrawl!

It's a snowball fight mixed with dodgeball!
Have a little holiday competition with this fun little addition to Fistful of Lead.

This game can be played with any miniatures you
have and for the most part use the standard Fistful of Lead Core rules.
You can have fights between evil snowmen and elves, Vikings and trolls, anything you can think of!

The game can be played with 2, 3 or 4 players.
Four player games can by 2 versus 2 or 4 way brawls.

THIS IS NOT A STAND ALONE GAME! You will need a copy of the Fistful of Lead Core rules.

—description from the publisher
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Fistful of Lead: Core Rulebook

boardgame.name: Mixed Blessings
boardgame.description:
Some Conditions May Apply

Self-righteous ascetics aside, delvers love loot. They especially appreciate rare and unique artifacts, which provide not only powers that enemies don't expect, but also something to brag about to allies (or anybody else who'll listen . . .). The difficulty with such things is that they bend, even break the rules in ways that give GMs headaches.

GURPS Dungeon Fantasy Treasures 4: Mixed Blessings solves this problem with items that fiddle the rules in ways that give munchkins headaches, too. They aren't cursed – far from it! – but they come with features that should make adventurers think twice about relying on them too much. Included is short-but-solid advice on creating your own mixed blessings, for which the 13 treasures in the collection serve as examples.

Void where prohibited by the laws of magic.

- Publisher's description

boardgame.name: Forgotten Treasure
boardgame.description:
Forgotten Treasure is a strategic and easy-to-learn turn-based card game from Wicked Magic Games. In this game, you are competing against fellow pirates to collect Treasures using various Keys, Items, and Defenses while protecting yourself against other players and dangerous Events.

The game is played over a varying number of rounds, all with the goal of being the first player to claim 4 Treasures. The first player to claim 4 Treasures is the winner.

Each turn you have two action points that can be used to draw cards, play Items, or claim Treasures.

There are five card types in the game: Treasures, Keys, Items, Defenses, and Events.
Treasures are the main goal of the game and provide you with helpful effects when claimed.
Keys are used to claim Treasures.
Items have a variety of effects that assist you in claiming Treasures or hinder other players.
Events are crazy, game-changing cards that are played immediately when drawn. So Events may cause to you keep your hand exposed to all players, while other might
force you to trade hands with other players.
Defenses are used to protect yourself from Events or stop other players from playing Item cards.

-description from designer
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Forgotten Treasure: Cursed Treasure Expansion

boardgame.name: Elf on the Stealth
boardgame.description:
Following in the tradition of "escape room in a box" games, Elf on the Stealth is an escape room in a Christmas card. Players attempt to track down the infamous mole that Big Plastic — an evil consortium of plastic-toy manufacturers — have placed within Santa's organization by solving puzzles, hunting down clues, and engaging in some lateral thinking.

The game comes in the form of a Christmas card that could be sent to friends or relatives with a cheery holiday message, which contains a link to a web app (written in simple JavaScript to be compatible with any smartphone, tablet, or PC) that mediates the game.

boardgame.name: Loto Fever
boardgame.description: "An exciting, fast-moving game for gamblers and all those who thrive on challenge." A card based take on traditional lottery/keno with players vying for the most cash and avoiding going bankrupt. Players ante each round for a number match card trying to match the six numbers on their lottery card to win the pot. Special instruction cards are thrown in to change things up when drawn. When a player or players complete their lottery card, all players that matched at least three of their six numbers get a trivia challenge card to try to win bonus cash. Those successful at the trivia challenge get the option do double their bonus winnings using the "match deck" paying for cards up to a certain amount trying to match their bonus number.

boardgame.name: Salt & Iron: Rules for Naval Battles During the American Civil War
boardgame.description:
You're standing lookout on the deck of the Union warship USS Cumberland anchored in Hampton Roads. The cold morning air bites through your coat. Through the fog laying over the bay you see a shape moving, you take it as nothing, seeing things from a late watch. You take a swig of coffee from your canteen to clear your head. Suddenly you see the shape move out of the fog. A great lumbering beast low in the water, black smoke billowing from its smokestack, flying the flag of the Confederacy. You sound the alarm, and watch as this beast begins to make its way towards your ship. You hear your shipmates start to bark orders, and the guns open up.
FDOOM! FDOOM! FDOOM! The cannonballs fly through the air at an incredible speed,
CLANG! CLANG! You stare in horror as the shots bounce off the shape, as if it were made of iron! Suddenly your ship lurches underneath you, throwing you to the deck. You regain your footing and see the nose of the beast buried in the hull of your ship. It reverses its engines and slowly pulls itself out opening the hole to the sea.

In Salt & Iron you can reenact famous naval battles from the American Civil War right on your tabletop!
These fast play rules are great for playing out any size battles in the matter of a couple hours.
These can be casual games amongst friends or historical scenarios to see if history can be rewritten.
What would have happened had Virginia destroyed Monitor, or if Monitor had even failed to arrive?

Every Civil War historian is very familiar with the great commanders such as David Farragut, Samuel Francis Du Pont, Franklin Buchanan, and Raphael Semmes.
With Salt & Iron, you can put yourself on the deck with them commanding some of their famous ships, along with many others.
There are many ships represented in Salt & Iron, plenty to take action in almost any scenario one can think up.

Now is the time Captain, prepare your fleet and lead daring actions against the enemy!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Dungeon Drawings Set #1
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Gamemasters! Put the excitement back into your campaign by skipping those long, tedious explanations of complicated rooms that wear you out and aggravate your players.

Our illustrated dungeon rooms save time and add realism to virtually any fantasy role-playing game. Rooms include both new and old monsters, shrines, crypts, traps, ruins, temples, statues and hallways...You key them and decide the color scheme.

Don't let a module push you around! You decide where treasure is, where monsters are, which items are trapped and which are magical.

boardgame.name: On Your Mark!: A Think On Your Feet, Track Building Game
boardgame.description:
You are an aspiring Olympic athlete who is training for the next Summer Olympics. You have decided the best way to improve your endurance is to create the most obnoxious and grueling track ever conceived! The longer the track the more in shape you will be when the games begin!

Players will be competing to create the longest track by drafting three track cards at a time and building on to their starting card. Any track segment that results in a dead end will not count towards your total distance, so make sure to plan for a way back to the starting line! In addition to track segments, players will occasionally come across Resource Cards which can be used to purchase Exhaustion Cards which if used correctly can earn the player a huge bonus.

The game ends when the cards run out, tally up your distance using the included scorepad and the player with the longest track wins!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Borderlands CYOA
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

You're riding a bus, driven by a really loud driver. He tells you some fairy tale about the Vault, and then drops you off. Welcome to PANDORA! Mineral reserves and alien technology made this planet a good mining opportunity for several corporations, but those dried up pretty quick. And when the money left, so did the corps, abandoning their workers. Most quickly went totally insane.

boardgame.name: Generic Gamer Jump
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Magic. Telekinesis. Super strength and speed. There are many great powers out there, but few so great as the power of the Gamer, of unchecked growth. For though you may appear in this world weak, you will undoubtedly leave it as one of the most powerful beings it has ever seen.

What world you appear in, specifically, is somewhat less important.

boardgame.name: Corona: Mit Eifer ins Geschäft
boardgame.description:
Compete to buy all the groceries on a shopping list for an elderly neighbour who is shielding against the virus.

The players collect and swap game cards, and the winner is whoever delivers all the items first. Hurdles along the way include encountering the virus, which sends you into quarantine, or finding that hoarders have already snapped up all the pasta or toilet rolls.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

boardgame.name: Blood: The Last Vampire – First Volume
Blood: The Last Vampire – Joukan
Blood: The Last Vampire – Volume 1
BLOOD: The Last Vampire – 上巻
boardgame.description:
In 2000, Production I.G. and Sony Computer Entertainment Japan co-produced a two-volume Blood: The Last Vampire video game. The game features a musical score by Yuki Kajiura with Youki Kudoh reprising her role as the voice of Saya, and over two hours of theater quality animation. It is a graphical adventure that brings Saya and her hunt for Chiropterans to Tokyo in 2000. There she meets a seventeen-year-old boy who begins wondering about Saya and the history of "Blood". Both volumes of the game were released to the PlayStation 2 in Japan on December 21, 2000. Famitsu magazine scored the first volume a 33 out of 40. Animerica's Dr. Brown called the original game "boring", but did compliment it for having "beautifully animated sequences".

Source: Wikipedia, "[en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blood%3A_The_Last_Vampire%23Video_games Blood: The Last Vampire]", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Blood: The Last Vampire
Yarudora Series Vol. 5: Blood: The Last Vampire
やるドラ ポータブル Blood the Last Vampire
boardgame.description:
In 2000, Production I.G. and Sony Computer Entertainment Japan co-produced a two-volume Blood: The Last Vampire video game. The game features a musical score by Yuki Kajiura with Youki Kudoh reprising her role as the voice of Saya, and over two hours of theater quality animation. It is a graphical adventure that brings Saya and her hunt for Chiropterans to Tokyo in 2000. There she meets a seventeen-year-old boy who begins wondering about Saya and the history of "Blood". Both volumes of the game were released to the PlayStation 2 in Japan on December 21, 2000. Famitsu magazine scored the first volume a 33 out of 40. Animerica's Dr. Brown called the original game "boring", but did compliment it for having "beautifully animated sequences".

In 2006, Production I.G and Sony re-released the game. Both volumes were combined into a single game for the PlayStation Portable (PSP). The game was released in Japan on January 26, 2006. The combined game included new cover art and additional features, including a strategy flow chart, a digital art gallery, and some exclusive films.

boardgame.name: In the Darkest of Times
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

PART ONE OF THE PUMPKIN SPICED ADVENTURES

A string of disappearing children? A mysterious green glow coming from the mountains? Phlan can’t seem to catch a break. Will you answer the call and help put a stop to the bad luck?

A Two-Hour Adventure for Tier 1 Characters. Optimized for APL 3.

This product includes:


Adventure PDF
Printer friendly PDF
Three VTT-ready maps

boardgame.name: 108 Town Names (Animal-Themed Names)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 real-life towns and cities with names that are perfect for your next animal-themed campaign, whether it's more "talking animal"-styled or anthro/furry-styled. I've got at least one settlement from almost every state in the U.S. and county in England.

This list has 60 towns and cities from the United States and 48 towns and cities from England, and includes names like Wolfeboro, NH; Elephant Butte, NM; and Pigeon Forge, TN. Check the preview for more.

boardgame.name: 108 Town Names (Fantasy-style Names)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 real-life towns and cities with names that are perfect for your next fantasy campaign (urban or otherwise). I've got at least one settlement from almost every state in the U.S. and county in England.

This list has 64 towns and cities from the United States and 44 towns and cities from England.

boardgame.name: 108 Sobriquets & Epithets
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 epithets, like "the Princeling" and "the Fratricide," which would be perfect for rulers in your next campaign.

boardgame.name: 108 Town Names (Ominous Names)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 real-life towns and cities with ominous-sounding names, perfect for your next horror adventure. I've got at least one settlement from almost every state in the U.S. and county in England.

This list has 68 towns and cities from the United States and 40 towns and cities from England.

boardgame.name: 108 Ancient Dishes & Beverages (Egypt)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 beverages, dishes, and snacks from Ancient Egypt. If your players want to know what they're eating and you don't have a PhD in Medieval Classical Studies, then look no further.

This list includes 16 beverages (medicinal wine!), 16 bread-based dishes, 11 porridges & soups & stews, 9 casseroles, 10 other seafood dishes (dried fish roe...?), 12 other egg & poultry dishes, 13 other meat dishes (baked hedgehog!), 11 dessert foods, and 14 other vegetable dishes.

boardgame.name: 108 Liminal Spaces
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 liminal beings, states, & spaces, perfect for dreamworlds, magicians, pantheons, horror campaigns, and anything else that would benefit from liminal symbolism.

Inside, you'll find liminal beings, states.

boardgame.name: 108 Obscure Monsters from Myth
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 little-known monsters from European mythology, along with adventure seeds, setting ideas, and other commentary for each one.

boardgame.name: 108 Medieval Dishes & Beverages (France)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 beverages, dishes, and snacks from Medieval France. If your players want to know what they're eating and you don't have a PhD in Medieval Studies, then look no further.

This list includes 8 beverages, 11 bread-based dishes, 17 fruit dishes, 23 porridges & soups, 11 other seafood dishes, 17 other meat dishes, 13 pies & tarts, 10 sauces, and 15 miscellaneous dishes that are harder to classify.

boardgame.name: 108 Solutions to the Fermi Paradox
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 solutions to the Fermi Paradox. Never again will you wonder where your setting's aliens are, or why Earth apparently has been contacted yet.

boardgame.name: 108 Magical Schools & Other Places to Learn Magic
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 magical schools and other places to learn magic. While they assume an urban fantasy kind of setting on Earth, they can be easily adapted for other universes.

boardgame.name: 108 Personal Names (Amharic/Ethiopian)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 personal names from the Amharic or Ethiopian language, with meanings included. Use them for Amharic-speaking or Ethiopian characters or as inspiration for fictional cultures.

This list has 54 male personal names and 54 female personal names. Male names can also be used as patronymic surnames without alteration (e.g. Meles, son of Dawit, would be known simply as “Meles Dawit,” rather than some form of “Meles Dawitson”)

boardgame.name: 108 Personal Names (Aztec)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 personal names from Aztec culture, with meanings included. Use them for Aztec characters or as inspiration for fictional cultures.

This list has 36 male personal names, 36 female personal names, and 36 unisex personal names.

boardgame.name: 108 Fictional Names (Orcish)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 personal names for orcs or another militant culture. These names have been designed to feel as though they belong to a single culture, so expect to spot common elements, be able to get a sense of how they fit together, and make more names that fit.

boardgame.name: 108 Medieval Dishes & Beverages (Germany)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 beverages, dishes, and snacks from Medieval Germany. If your players want to know what they're eating and you don't have a PhD in Medieval Studies, then look no further.

This list includes 18 beverages, 11 bread-based dishes, 17 fruit dishes, 12 pies & sausages, 18 soups & stews, 19 other meat dishes, and 13 miscellaneous dishes that are harder to classify. It pairs well with 108 Medieval European Crops.

boardgame.name: 108 Superpower Origins
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 origins for your superhero (or supervillain)! Never show your players a bog standard supervillain (or hero) again!

boardgame.name: 108 Weird But Real Currencies
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 forms of money. If you've ever wanted someone in your setting to use something other than cash or gold coins, then look no further.

boardgame.name: 108 Medieval Dishes & Beverages (England)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 beverages, dishes, and snacks from Medieval England. If your players want to know what they're eating and you don't have a PhD in Medieval Studies, then look no further.

This list includes 18 beverages, 13 bread-based dishes, 12 fruit dishes, 21 porridges & stews, 30 other meat dishes, and 14 miscellaneous dishes that are harder to classify. It pairs well with 108 Medieval European Crops.

boardgame.name: 108 Encounters with Zombies
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 ways to tell your players that they've come across a zombie. Each encounter has a story behind it, if your players want to dig into it rather than run in the opposite direction, and can be adapted for other kinds of monsters.

boardgame.name: 108 Medieval Crops
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 Medieval European crops. Never again will you leave your players' suspension of disbelief broken because you forgot that potatoes and pumpkins are out of place for Fantasy Not-Europe!

This list includes 30 fruits, 11 grains, 24 herbs, 11 nuts and legumes, and 32 vegetables, along with a little bit of information on each. It pairs well with 108 Medieval English Beverages, Dishes, & Snacks.

boardgame.name: 108 Personal Names & Surnames (Basque)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 personal names and surnames from Basque culture, with meanings included. Use them for Basque characters or as inspiration for fictional cultures.

This list has 40 male personal names, 40 female personal names, and 28 surnames.

boardgame.name: 108 Bear-themed Monsters
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 bear-themed monsters (or friends, with a good Diplomacy roll!), perfect for that Night of 1,001 Bears session that I know you've been planning forever.

boardgame.name: 108 Clown Names
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 clown names, each one developed according to advice from real clowns on Clown-Forum.com. You can't get much more official than that! Use them for clowns of all varieties: doctor clowns, serial killer clowns, robot clowns, spider-demon clowns, happy clowns, killer clowns from outer space...

boardgame.name: 108 Superpowers or Spells
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This is exactly what it says on the tin: a list of 108 ideas for superpowers (or spells, if you're running a fantasy game). Never show your players a bog standard supervillain (or hero) again!

Inside, you'll find superpowers or spells.

boardgame.name: The Salt Cyclopedia of Comparative Mythology
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Your average book on mythology will tell about, say, Hades, and in the course of it mention that he was a death divinity. If you want to learn about death divinities in general, then you've still got a lot of work ahead of you.

This book approaches things from the opposite direction, which should be useful for worldbuilders. Rather than tell you about individual gods, this book explains how death divinities have worked across the world and then gives Hades and some other gods as examples.

With The Salt Cyclopedia at your side, you have all the tools that you need to start building a pantheon that is fresh and full of new life at the same time that it feels real, as though it's an authentic mythological system that just hadn't been uncovered until now. It includes not only basic mythemes but also discussions on divine epithets, fusing multiple gods together, building non-standard portfolios, and more.

boardgame.name: The Meaning of Names: Landforms, Terrain, and Cities
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

There are many good resources out there for creating new languages, but they tend to focus more on how words change over time than on the meanings of place-names. This booklet is intended to fill the gap. It not only includes lists of historical place-names but discusses the patterns and logic behind these names.

boardgame.name: The Meaning of Names: Persons and Peoples
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

There are many good resources out there for creating new languages, but they tend to focus more on how words change over time than on the meanings of personal or group names.

This booklet is intended to fill the gap. It not only includes lists of historical names (personal, family, and ethnic) but discusses the patterns and logic behind these names.
boardgame.rpgartist: United States National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)

boardgame.name: Horse Nomads
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Generally, designing a culture for a book or a game presents you with a choice: either you base it on real-world cultures and likely end up with something that could be described as "Fantasy Bedouin with some Navajo bits tacked on" or you run hog wild and run the risk of overlooking something that, however innocuous, turns out to be vitally important for that type of culture.

There's another way to handle this dilemma, though. By researching each culture of a given type and taking note of their common characteristics, you can create a plausibly-developed culture that doesn't noticeably take its cues from any real-world counterparts. That would take an enormous amount of effort, though, but luckily for you I've gone ahead and spent the time, bought the books, and pored over the scientific journals so that you don't have to!

How-To: Horse Nomads is a summary of the characteristics that were held in common by horse nomads on both the Eurasian Steppe and the American Plains.

boardgame.name: Far North Peoples
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Generally, designing a culture for a book or a game presents you with a choice: either you base it on real-world cultures and likely end up with something that could be described as "Fantasy Bedouin with some Navajo bits tacked on" or you run hog wild and run the risk of overlooking something that, however innocuous, turns out to be vitally important for that type of culture.

There's another way to handle this dilemma, though. By researching each culture of a given type and taking note of their common characteristics, you can create a plausibly-developed culture that doesn't noticeably take its cues from any real-world counterparts. That would take an enormous amount of effort, though, but luckily for you I've gone ahead and spent the time, bought the books, and pored over the scientific journals so that you don't have to!

How-To: Far North Peoples is a summary of the characteristics that were held in common by people living in the circumpolar region of the world, from Finland to Alaska to Greenland.

boardgame.name: Hill Tribes
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Generally, designing a culture for a book or a game presents you with a choice: either you base it on real-world cultures and likely end up with something that could be described as "Fantasy Bedouin with some Navajo bits tacked on" or you run hog wild and run the risk of overlooking something that, however innocuous, turns out to be vitally important for that type of culture.

That would take an enormous amount of effort, though, but luckily for you I've gone ahead and spent the time, bought the books, and pored over the scientific journals so that you don't have to!

How-To: Hill Tribes is a summary of the characteristics that were held in common by people living in the circumpolar region of the world, from Finland to Alaska to Greenland.

boardgame.name: Swamp Folk
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Generally, designing a culture for a book or a game presents you with a choice: either you base it on real-world cultures and likely end up with something that could be described as "Fantasy Bedouin with some Navajo bits tacked on" or you run hog wild and run the risk of overlooking something that, however innocuous, turns out to be vitally important for that type of culture.

By researching each culture of a given type and taking note of their common characteristics, you can create a plausibly-developed culture that doesn't noticeably take its cues from any real-world counterparts. That would take an enormous amount of effort, though, but luckily for you I've gone ahead and spent the time, bought the books, and pored over the scientific journals so that you don't have to!

How-To: Swamp Folk is a summary of the characteristics that were held in common by wetland-dwelling cultures (from bogs to marshes to swamps).

boardgame.name: Mollusks & Other Lophotrochozoans
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

It's easy to make aliens: take a person or a dog, slap some antennae on 'em, maybe some ooze and some spooky talons, and then put some random letters together in a nigh-unpronounceable combination.

As I said, it's easy to make aliens. What isn't easy is making them well.

Even when you're working hard to be creative, it can sometimes be hard to get out of the rut of familiarity, to go beyond four limbs and two eyes and venture into the realm of, well, the alien.

This series is about exploring the diversity of forms already lurking around us, breaking them down into short summaries so that you can use them as a jumping-off point for new forms of life and talking about some of the ways that they could be twisted around. By the time that you're done, nobody will guess that your original inspiration was a worm or a clam.

boardgame.name: Hexapods and Other Ecdysozoa
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

It's easy to make aliens: take a person or a dog, slap some antennae on 'em, maybe some ooze and some spooky talons, and then put some random letters together in a nigh-unpronounceable combination.

As I said, it's easy to make aliens. What isn't easy is making them well.

Even when you're working hard to be creative, it can sometimes be hard to get out of the rut of familiarity, to go beyond four limbs and two eyes and venture into the realm of, well, the alien.

This series is about exploring the diversity of forms already lurking around us, breaking them down into short summaries so that you can use them as a jumping-off point for new forms of life and talking about some of the ways that they could be twisted around. By the time that you're done, nobody will guess that your original inspiration was a spider or a velvet worm.

boardgame.name: Island Builders & Others
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

It's easy to make aliens: take a person or a dog, slap some antennae on 'em, maybe some ooze and some spooky talons, and then put some random letters together in a nigh-unpronounceable combination.

As I said, it's easy to make aliens. What isn't easy is making them well.

Even when you're working hard to be creative, it can sometimes be hard to get out of the rut of familiarity, to go beyond four limbs and two eyes and venture into the realm of, well, the alien.

This series is about exploring the diversity of forms already lurking around us, breaking them down into short summaries so that you can use them as a jumping-off point for new forms of life and talking about some of the ways that they could be twisted around. By the time that you're done, nobody will guess that your original inspiration was a spider or a velvet worm.

boardgame.name: Funerary Cannibals & Others
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

One of the quickest ways to start building cultures for your setting is to take inspiration from actually-existing cultures. What do you do when you don't want to crib off the same culture cultures that everyone else has used a hundred times before?

Essential Ethnographies offers the convenience of building from preexisting cultures and the flexibility and novelty of working with cultures that are less familiar to your players or readers. Whether it’s half-elves inspired by the oldest inhabitants of Europe, humans living in the coldest north (or south!), ogres that see their cannibalism as an act of benevolence, or aliens with a kind of ritualized policing, this series aims to make your job easy.

boardgame.name: Cousins of the Bear & Others
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

One of the quickest ways to start building cultures for your setting is to take inspiration from actually-existing cultures. What do you do when you don't want to crib off the same culture cultures that everyone else has used a hundred times before?

Essential Ethnographies offers the convenience of building from preexisting cultures and the flexibility and novelty of working with cultures that are less familiar to your players or readers. Whether it’s half-elves inspired by the oldest inhabitants of Europe, humans living in the coldest north (or south!), ogres that see their cannibalism as an act of benevolence, or aliens with a kind of ritualized policing, this series aims to make your job easy.

boardgame.name: Necrocracies: Eight Governments of the Dead
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Political Fantasies is a series that takes names for governments and plays around with them to see how far they can be pulled. In the tradition of Strange Nations, the results of each exploration can be dropped into your setting with little-to-no adaptation required.

This volume explores necrocracy or "rule by the dead," with possibilities like restricting the vote to dead people (and how you might accomplish that, even without magic), cults ruling in the name of long-deceased kings, and mausoleum-cities. Each one makes some assumptions about the setting, like whether the presence of magic or the level of technology, but it won't take much work to make them more suitable for other settings.

boardgame.name: Thalassocracy: On Maritime and Spacefaring Empires
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Political Fantasies is a series that takes names for governments and plays around with them to see how far they can be pulled. In the tradition of Strange Nations, the results of each exploration can be dropped into your setting with little-to-no adaptation required.

This volume explores thalassocracy, or "rule by the sea." The first section discusses the common traits of maritime empires--the default meaning of thalassocracy--so that you can better design them for your own settings. The second section is more fantastical, exploring how a thalassocracy might be realized in space and playing with a few short cultures that you can drop into your setting and alter or expand on as necessary.

boardgame.name: Corporatocracy: Company Rule in Fact & Fantasy
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Political Fantasies is a series that takes names for governments and plays around with them to see how far they can be pulled. In the tradition of Strange Nations, the results of each exploration can be dropped into your setting with little-to-no adaptation required.

This volume explores corporatocracy, or "rule by corporations." The first chapter, Market Analysis, explores the ways that “corporatocracy” can apply in real life: banana republics, company towns, governments that are a little too friendly to business interests, and so on. It is followed by Case Studies, which discusses some historical corporatocracies, such as the Dutch and British East India Companies. Finally, Wild Speculation has a few fictional corporatocracies that you can drag and drop into your setting with little no adaptation required.

boardgame.name: Primates and Bats: Speculative Psychology for Uplifted Animals
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Are you looking to mine a few ideas for the batfolk in your upcoming adventure, The Diamond Mines of Camazotz? Writing some Planet of the Apes fanfiction and wondering what kind of sports gorillas might play?

If so, then look no further! Whether you're working on uplifted animals, animal folk, or just plain talking animals, this book can be used for it all.

Primates and Bats discusses apes, bats, monkeys, and prosimians. A page is given to each group as a whole, and a little more attention is given to five representative species for each group.

boardgame.name: Agloanikoi - The Gameplayers
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Worldbuilding can be hard, especially when it comes to aliens. All too often, fictional aliens feel like they're really just humans in costumes. Even when they are weird enough to feel truly nonhuman, they're usually still suffering from a serious case of monoculture-itis. Species Shock aims to supply you with truly alien extraterrestrials, covering everything from planet of origin to biology, culture, a few of their thoughts about humans.

This violume features the Agloanikoi, or aglos, a species of many-legged tree-dwelling aliens that are carbon-based and breathe oxygen, like us, but evolved on a world where jaws never developed and the most common form of blood is cobalt-based.

Sexually dimorphism is nothing new, but the aglos carry it to extremes rarely found on Earth: the males are herbivorous and the females are carnivorous. The sexes differ in other behaviors as well, including their spiritual inclinations, social behaviors, and the females' fondness for ritual battles that the xenolinguists translate as "flowery warfare." This phenomenon is one of the chief forces responsible for the shaping of their society, as influential to their history as monarchies and capitalism have been to our own.

boardgame.name: Aliens, Dystopias, & Monster Ecologies: Worldbuilding Essays for Writers and GMs
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Aliens, Dystopias, & Monster Ecologies is a series of worldbuilding essays on alien psychologies and ethical systems, functional dystopias, recreating vampires and werewolves, original elemental systems, and figuring out just how many human-eating monsters your setting can support.

boardgame.name: Becoming a Better Writer Through Roleplaying & Other Essays on Writing
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Aliens, Dystopias, & Monster Ecologies is a series of worldbuilding essays on alien psychologies and ethical systems, functional dystopias, recreating vampires and werewolves, original elemental systems, and figuring out just how many human-eating monsters your setting can support.

boardgame.name: Rule of Three
boardgame.description:
Rule of Three is a fast-paced strategy game for visual thinkers. Shuffle the cards and prepare to collect matching triplets of shapes, colors, and numbers. Can you outwit the other players and steal the cards they need?

In this game players score points by matching sets. A matching set is any three cards that share two qualities from the following: Color, or Shape, or Number of Bars. Wild cards are also part of the game, and enable you to form a set with cards sharing two qualities.

A round ends when a player has 3 matching sets, scoring them 3 points. Players with 1 or 2 matching sets score -1 point, and players with no matching sets score -3 points. The first player to score 10 points wins.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Aqua Garden: Outdoor Expansion
아쿠아 가든: 아웃도어 확장
boardgame.description:
In the Kickstarter-exclusive Outdoor Expansion for Aqua Garden, the player now has an additional tank, the Outdoor aquarium.

Each player will receive a unique meeple - either a whale, an orca, a dolphin or a sea lion - each having a unique ability, as well as a special outdoor tank. Once per round, the player has the option of placing a creature in the outdoor aquarium instead of the indoor ones, to either gain 2 funds or activate special abilities.

The Outdoor Expansion also adds a new type of advanced pieces: the Jellyfish, which counts as a joker fish piece to complete milestones.
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Aqua Garden

boardgame.name: Aqua Garden: Kickstarter Rewards
아쿠아 가든: 개복치 미니 확장
boardgame.description:
This mini expansion, which is exclusive to the Kickstarter backers, introduces three different animals to the game: the Pufferfish, the Sunfish and the Japanese Spider Crab. Each allows the player to gain Victory Points in unique ways:

The Sunfish grants 2 Victory Points for each set of 3 funds you still have at the end of the game.
The Pufferfish grants 1 Victory Point for each Coral token in the player's aquarium.
The Japanese Spider Crab grants 1 Victory Point for each advanced fish token in the player's aquarium, itself included.


This pack also includes a unique Spotted Garden Eel meeple to replace the scoring marker cube from the base game.
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Aqua Garden

boardgame.name: Alarums & Excursions (Issue 542 - Jan 2021)
boardgame.description:
Alarums & Excursions
Issue 542
January 2021
Ignorable Theme: Thieves — What sort of things do they steal? When and where and how do they steal? Whom do they steal from?

boardgame.name: Admirals War: Expansion
boardgame.description: Admirals' War Expansion is a new expansion of the Admirals' War base game that incorporates the Black Sea, new submarine rules, Plan Orange scenarios, as well as three new counter-sheets full of new ships.
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Admirals' War: World War II at Sea

listing.notes: New Copy in Shrink.

This is a brandnew, sealed copy. Latest edition. Fresh from Kickstarter. USA shipping $14.25 (Medium Flat Rate Box). Can combine shipping for multiple games.
3 lbs 13x10x4 inch

boardgame.name: Jinshu Niu, the Metal Ox
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

In honor of the Lunar New Year, we have released the Jinshu Niu! This publication includes a detailed D&D 5E description and stats for the “Metal Ox” of the Asian Zodiac, along with details for two variants and the effects of particular years on them. It is the perfect addition to anything from a traditional fantasy campaign setting to one with East Asian or Wuxia elements.

Jinshu Niu are creatures from the Elemental Plane of Earth that look like oxen made of metal, silver in the case of males and gold in the case of females, and which have eyes that appear to be spheres of semi-precious stone. They are very rare on the Prime Material Plane and those present on it will likely be found in isolated places like ancient bamboo forests or places where they can indefatigably perform the sorts of labor they love so much.

Such creatures do, in fact, thrive on physically demanding undertakings that would be onerous even to beings bred for such things, and are often kept by Earth-dwelling beings like Dao as draft animals; by Dragons, which tend to view them as living treasures that can double as tireless guardians of their hoards; and by people that include great landowners and master architects, builders, and craftsmen. They also sometimes dwell in the temples of various deities, where they typically serve as companion animals or guardians.

In cultures that observe the Lunar New Year and adhere to the Asian Zodiac, spellcasters often summon Metal Oxen to take part in annual celebrations. Such creatures are then displayed, marched in parades and used to pull things like immense juggernaut carts or mobile shrines; doted on; and otherwise honored for the duration of their stays. Powerful spellcasters and other beings also sometimes summon Metal Oxen to perform prodigious or even legendary tasks, such as tilling unplowable fields, moving structures like palaces or temples, destroying gates or walls of enemy citadels, and the like.

boardgame.name: Nagashino 1575 & Shizugatake 1583
boardgame.description:
Nagashino 1575 & Shizugatake 1583 is the first volume of a serie dedicated to Sengoku jidai . It consists of a double-sided zone map, 216 beautifully illustrated counters, 24 pages rulebook - French and English - , one game aid and two scenarios. The scale is 300m per zone, 45 minutes per game turn and 500 men per counter. A game lasts 2 to 4 hours and is ideally for 2 players.

The Battle of Nagashino 1575 marks a tactical turning point in the wars in Japan of the Sengoku jidai (1467-1615) or Warring states; Daimyo Oda's army, made up of ashigaru teppo (infantrymen equipped with arquebuses) supported by ashigaru naga-yari and yumi (pike and bow) defeat the terrible charges of the samurai cavalry of the Takeda clan.
As for the Battle of Shizugatake 1583, it is unique in its kind as it takes place on the heights of a wooded mountain and begins in the middle of the night ...
Prepare for fast and bloody battles where tactics are essential!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Battlelords GM Screen for 6th Edition
Carnage Screen: Battle Master's Game Screen
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Carnage Screen! Everything a Battle Master needs to push their players through the meat grinder of life as an expendible mercenary. This GM Screen has 5 pages of useful charts for the 6th Edition of Battlelords of the Twenty-Third Century all in one convenient place - including the infamous Battlelords Critical Hit Chart.
boardgame.rpg: Battlelords of the Twenty-Third Century (5th & 6th Editions)

boardgame.name: Fragged Cyberpunk
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

"A dystopian far-future Cyberpunk where humans seek to overcome the weakness of flesh and avoid extinction through AUGs and submission."

A prequal to Fragged Empire, set within the final years of humanity during the Age of Gnawing just before the creation of the Archons in the Nega megacity.

Has EVERYTHING you need to play!

Full lore & rules.
LOADS of content! (9 Forms (Meat Kebab, Forlorn, Scrapper, Can, Prime, Freak, Hologram, Bot and Software), 132+ Augmentations, 300+ Weapon combinations, misc items, pre-made NPCs, etc...).

boardgame.name: Expanding Codex
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Expanding Codex fleshes out monsters from the Creature Codex, giving GMs ways to modify the existing monsters to surprise well-prepared players or to introduce monsters to a campaign. At a full 32 pages, the Expanding Codex brings you variant monsters and magic inspired by the pages of the Creature Codex:

17 variant monsters from Creature Codex, including the swolbold, drakes, and unhatched
22 new magic items from the Periapt of Proof Against Lies to the Firesight Goggles
26 new spells including mindless vengeance and siege of iron
Plus adventure hooks, 2 feats, and a ranger companion!


Add these variant monsters to your campaign with alternate traits and actions, or outfit your characters with new spells and items inspired by the monsters. Either way, prepare for adventure, choosing from a slew of adventure hooks!

boardgame.name: The Toymaker and the Bag of Gifting
boardgame.description:
"The Toymaker and the Bag of Gifting is a 2-4 hour Christmas-themed one shot adventure for five 8th-12th level characters. This is a light-hearted adventure with a Christmas spin appropriate for all player levels. Tweak the encounter difficulty if your party is not yet levels 8-12. The narration in this adventure is written in rhyme ala Dr. Seuss. Have fun with it!

This adventure is kid friendly as well, just maybe tone down the violence and tweak a narrative line or two (Toymaker says a swear).

Adventure Summary
The Toymaker has gone missing and brave heroes are needed to find him. After discovering the evil Count Von Grump has stolen the Toymaker’s enchanted Bag of Gifting, they must retrieve the bag and fight off the grumpy villain before distributing presents all around Faerun before sunrise. They will have a dangerous snowball fight with frost giants, encounter a nasty gnome named Missile-Toe who shoots magic missiles from his socks, and then fly through the air and take on the villainous Count Von Grump in an aerial encounter your party won’t forget!"

(Author Summary)

boardgame.name: Ninja: Silent But Deadly – Rick Roll!
boardgame.description: A Rick Astley joke promo card for Ninja: Silent But Deadly with a Wild Cats back, so you can slide your Ninja Rick Roll! card in a Wild Cats game!

boardgame.name: Work From Home
boardgame.description:
WORK FROM HOME is a fast-paced, competitive card game that is full of distractions. The purpose of the game is to make the most money by completing your assigned work tasks; however, text messages, crying babies, and many other distractions make it tough to focus. WORK FROM HOME takes only 3 minutes to learn and 10 minutes to play, and is family-friendly fun for everyone.

Coming to Kickstarter March 2021.

boardgame.name: Holiday Adventures
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Are You Ready to Save Christmas?

Seelie Squad is the codename for Faerie’s daring, highly trained, special mission force. Its purpose: to defend mortal freedom against the Unseelie, a ruthless organization determined to ruin the holidays!

It’s not just Christmas; Seelie Squad is responsible for ensuring holidays all over the world go off without a hitch so mortals everywhere can enjoy “meraki,” the joy of a holiday that spreads wonder. Without it, mortals might stop believing entirely and the portals between worlds will be permanently closed. Did we mention that you’re just one foot tall?

So if you have what it takes to stuff stockings, deliver gifts, and face down giant pets, strap on your grappling hook and darkvision goggles because Seelie Squad needs you!

This supplement features 3 species and 9 subspecies to play, 11 new pieces of equipment, 22 new monsters, rules for playing a tiny creature in a big world, and limitless houses to explore.

boardgame.name: Aquatica: Raum the Cruel & Nerine the Law Keeper promo cards
아쿠아티카: 잔혹한 라움 & 법의 수호자 네린
boardgame.description:
2 promo cards that introduce new King cards to Aquatica. Originally given away at SPIEL 19 and other conventions.

9 - Raum the Cruel: Conquer 1 location and raise it all up.

10 - Nerine the Law Keeper: Copy the effect of the upper card from any other player's discard.
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Aquatica

boardgame.name: DC Comics HeroClix: Wonder Woman 80th Anniversary Miniatures Game
boardgame.description:
Standalone awesomeness! Play up to 8 campaign scenarios for 2 players where results matter from session to session or sit down for a head to head single match of raw power! Each of the 10 beautiful ready to play figures comes with two different ways to play for hundreds of different combinations. Excellent point of entry for the first time miniatures player! Map components are thick double sided and the box includes everything you need to play!

This miniatures game contains everything 2 people need to play HeroClix:

A meaty multi-session campaign for 2 players that pivots and turns based on the results of the last session
10 Premium Quality Pre-Painted Miniatures each with TWO ways to play for beginner or advanced play
20 Character Cards
18 Object, Terrain, and Bystander tokens
6 Double-Sided Thick Map Tiles. No folds!
2 Custom Wonder Woman six-sided dice
2 All-new Powers and Abilities Cards with Wonder Woman imagery
1 All-New Full-Color HeroClix Core Rulebook (2021 edition)
This boxed-set is a great way for 2 players to learn HeroClix! Existing players will definitely want to pick up this product since it includes tournament-worthy figures as well as an updated Rulebook and Powers and Abilities Card available for the first time ever!

Wonder Woman is the Champion of Themyscira, one of the strongest people on Earth, hero to all Amazons, and a connection between Gods and mortals. What perils will face her on the HeroClix tabletop?!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: The Complete Illustrated Book of Transmutation
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Complete Illustrated Book of Transmutation

Contains all 98 Transmutation spells compatible with Dungeons and Dragons 5e
Beautifully illustrated
There is a grimoire in the back for your homebrew spells

boardgame.name: Festival of Fights: Merry Heistmas II
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Merry Hesitmas fringer!

Here is the second of our holiday season one-shot series. This time, 3V Capital is looking to spoil the holiday season for hundreds of people in Angel City. They intend on evicting hundreds of their tenants on Christmas Eve. It’s up to the player group to team up with St. Nikki (from last year) to find their holiday spirit, grab Santa's 8 massive ROVdeer, wrap it up real nice, turn it sideways, and stick it back the Corp.

If you miss it Yule be sorry!

boardgame.name: A Royal Will
boardgame.description:
Death, woe, tragedy... and Opportunity?

"Euphoria, once the peaceful center of the Andromeda galaxy, a crossroad for kingdoms and solardoms, has plummeted into treachery and chaos.

With the unexplained deaths of its royal family, assets that can buy nebulas are up for grabs, and everyone has a tactic to try to alter the wills in their favor…”

A royal game of galactic greed. Form strategic character pairings using just 2 cards to win The Wills. One character acts to disrupt the Inheritance, the other steals the wealth. There’s a craft to high-stakes thievery: greed will leave your pockets empty, but caution will profit your enemies. Play your cards right, and the wealth of Euphoria shall be yours!

—description from the designer

Welcome to Vancouver, a city unknowingly at the epicenter of a world-changing discovery.

“City of Glass” is a full IDENTECO adventure for players levels 0-3 in the Vancouver Metroplex. It’s a heist mission where they must dodge rival gangs, Corp security, and one aloof mid-level Corp manager to hijack information he knows about his organization’s secret project.

Player handouts

boardgame.name: Fort mit Schaden!
boardgame.description:
The players start on space 1 and have to get to space 120 to win the game. Movement is determined by a die. One some spaces events hinder or benefit the players. Players who can recite the matching verse about damage prevention avoid the penalty and get a reward instead.

The game was published in accordance with the "Reichsarbeitsgemeinschaft Schadensverhütung" between 1936 and 1944.
